Empires and Puzzles Zaria Review: The Three-Eyed Psychic

Zaria brings a unique tile-counting mechanic to the battlefield, threatening massive damage if the board aligns. But with average speed and stats showing their age, does her prediction of victory still hold true? We consult the cards (and the math) to find out.
Zaria Review: Is This Psychic Granny Still Predicting Victories?
Zaria: The Three-Eyed Oracle Who Demands a Red Carpet (of Tiles)

Zaria is a 5-star Legendary Fire hero from the Super Elemental family, originally released in late 2023. She arrived with the Contest of Elements, bringing a mechanic that scales damage based on the number of elemental shields on the board. In a game full of mighty warriors and mythical beasts, Zaria stands out as a creepy, elderly fortune teller who looks like she just cursed your entire lineage because you didn't tip her. She operates as a pure damage dealer (AoE), with her potency directly tied to your puzzle-matching luck.

The artwork for Zaria is distinctively unsettling. She isn't your typical armored knight or ethereal elf; she’s a haggard seer with long, white hair and a literal third eye on her forehead that probably sees all your bad board movements before you make them. She holds a glowing orb of fire, perhaps reading a future where you actually get 12 red tiles (spoiler: it's a rare future). The background features tarot cards floating in a mystical void, reinforcing her theme of divination. It’s a bold design choice that leans heavily into the "witch of the wilds" aesthetic.
When Zaria was released, her attack stat of 999 was considered sky-high. However, looking at the current landscape of late 2025, she has fallen behind significantly. Modern damage dealers like

boast attack stats over 1300 and health pools exceeding 2200. Zaria's defense (945) and health (1586) leave her quite fragile by today's standards. While she can still punch hard thanks to her high base attack for her era, she is essentially a "glass cannon" that has become more glass than cannon over time. She needs protection to survive long enough to cast her spell, especially given her Average speed.
Zaria's special skill is a classic "high risk, high reward" mechanic, but the "risk" is mostly just RNG frustration.
She deals 250% damage to all enemies. At Average speed, this is underwhelming in the current meta. Many modern heroes hit harder at Fast speed or provide significant utility alongside the damage.
Damage increases to 300%. This is her realistic "good" scenario. 300% to all is a solid hit, comparable to older heavy hitters, but rarely team-wiping on its own against modern boosted-health teams.

Damage increases to 500%. This is the "nuke" option. If you pull this off, you likely win the match. However, holding 12 tiles while charging an Average speed hero is a delicate dance that often results in Zaria dying before she can fire.
With a Level 23+ Mana Troop (or Level 11+ Magic/Styx/Cyclops), this drops to
class +20 talent node gives +4% mana generation. Combined with a decent mana troop, she can comfortably charge in 9 tiles (3 matches).
(Fast speed) deals 385% to one and 255% to others with ~1200 Attack. Zaria's base hit is weaker and slower. Her max hit is devastating but statistically improbable in standard PvP.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family brings some interesting mechanics that try to compensate for the mono-color playstyle they encourage.

The Power Gem mechanic is a double-edged sword. It generates passive damage (20 per turn) and small AoE damage (10 per match). It's a nice bonus that adds up over a long fight, especially in bloody battles, but it won't save you if the board is dry.

This is excellent for tile damage. Dealing +100% extra elemental damage against Nature enemies makes her a Titan specialist. The damage reduction from Ice enemies (-10%) helps her survivability slightly against her weak element, but mostly you bring her to kill Green things.
is the perfect Aether Power for her. Since she is a pure damage dealer, every point of attack helps scale that percentage-based hit. It doesn't add utility, but it sharpens her only tool.

Upon release, Zaria was met with skepticism. Community members quickly pointed out that her beta version was nerfed (originally 420% damage at 6 tiles), and the live version's 300% felt lackluster for an Average speed hero. The 12-tile condition was widely regarded as a "unicorn" scenario—magical if it happens, but you can't build a strategy around it.

Zaria has aged poorly. In an era where heroes deal 400%+ damage to all at Fast speed or introduce insane mechanics like "Insanity" or "Wither," a conditional 300% hitter at Average speed struggles to find a place. Her stats are the biggest liability; she melts under the pressure of modern snipers and slash attacks.

. Her best use case is in Rush Attack wars/tournaments where her speed is mitigatable, or against Nature Titans where her passive and tile damage shine. For standard Raids or Wars, she is mostly a benchwarmer unless you lack modern Red options.
Zaria currently does not have a costume.
Zaria is a Sorcerer. While the class talent (Delay) is decent for defense, you are bringing Zaria for one reason: Damage.
Maximizes the damage of her special skill and her tiles. If she hits the 12-tile condition, you want that multiplier to work off the highest possible base attack.
She remains squishy and may die before firing.
Helps her survive long enough to gather the necessary tiles.
Her 250% base hit becomes negligible against modern defenses.
path is recommended. If you are using her, you are gambling on a big hit. Don't hedge your bets; go full damage.
Her passive Troop Mastery dealing +100% extra elemental damage against Nature makes her a top-tier tile damage dealer for Green Titans.
The 500% damage tier, while rare, is a game-ending move.
The Delay talent can occasionally disrupt enemy mana, which is a nice bonus on a damage dealer.
Her damage output fluctuates wildly based on the board. You can't rely on her to do her job consistently.
Her defensive stats make her a liability in modern raid formations.
Average speed is too slow for a hero who offers no utility (cleanse, dispel, buffs) other than pure damage.
getting 6 red tiles usually means you
made two matches, leaving you with fewer tiles when she actually fires.
This is her home. The passive damage boost is significant.
At Very Fast speed, the pressure to find tiles to charge her is gone, allowing you to focus on
tiles on the board for her damage boost.
If you use mana potions to charge her while the board is full of red tiles, she can wipe waves instantly.
Since Zaria needs red tiles on the board
, she pairs poorly with other Red heroes that consume tiles quickly (like converters).
Use a Scroll of Alteration to flood the board with Red tiles. This triggers Zaria's 12+ tile condition (500% damage) AND ensures massive tile damage from her passive.
In Rush, Zaria fires often. Attacking into her is risky because if you (the attacker) leave red tiles on the board, she punishes you harder.
Zaria hits everyone. If she hits a team with Reposte up, she will instantly kill herself.
Neutering her attack stat renders her useless.
Heroes that shuffle the board might ruin your setup of 12 tiles right before you cast.

If you pulled Zaria early in your journey, she is a fantastic damage dealer. Her "low" stats are only low compared to the top 1%; for map stages and early raids, 250-300% AoE damage is excellent. Level her up, but don't prioritize her over essential healers or utility heroes.

Zaria is likely a luxury toy for you. She is fun to use when you want to see big numbers, but she isn't reliable enough for competitive wars. Do not use Alpha Aethers on her unless you are chasing Titan high scores and need the Attack stat padding. There are simply better Red heroes (like
) who do more with less effort.
The community reaction to Zaria was largely mixed-to-negative due to the "beta nerf."
"200% to all at average speed in worst case doesn’t seem Cataclysmic enough to me."
"That old hag is creepy... clearly, she didn’t age like fine wine."
The general consensus is that the 12-tile condition is a gimmick:
"I have yet to see 12 tiles when she's charged... they seem much better on defense."
Many players compared her unfavorably to
, who offer more consistent damage or utility without the hoop-jumping.

Zaria is a hero who promises the moon (or the cataclysm) but often delivers a mild sunburn. While her artwork is wonderfully witchy and her Titan utility is undeniable, she suffers from being a "conditional" hero in a game that increasingly rewards consistency and speed. She is the fortune teller who predicts you're going to lose the match because you couldn't find that 12th red tile.
Keep her for Green Titans and Rush Wars, but leave her on the bench for serious business.
N/A (Let's hope a future costume gives her a walker and a shotgun).
